setup.question: What is the relationship between Gavin and the First Officer like?
answers: Gavin trusts him so much as to go together on space expeditions, but not further
Gavin learns important lessons in leadership from him

Text.text: No Opinion.
Context: Gavin is a new captain leading an experienced crew, and he doesn't completely trust anyone:

They encounter a blackout, and he argues with Quade about the cause. He sends out an exploration party but returns none the wiser. Here, First officer Nagurski attempts to talk to Gav, but he sacrastically shuts down the convo:
and continues cutting him off throughout the story, showcasing his lack of complete trust:

. 

Gav repeatedly says to Nag -
showing his limited trust.
the relationship between Gavin and the FO is all about Gavin learning important lessons through the FO's failures.  for example Gavin proclaims these things:
. He even realizes he needs to demote Quade:

.

A can't be right, Gavin clearly trusts him going beyond just going on space expeditions. Can provide ev next speech ran out of quote space. It shouldn't be necessary.

I'd like some clash on the framing. A seems to say the crew (including FO) is more experienced and that causes some insecurity and trust issues, and B says the FO is somewhat incompetent and teaches valuable lessons. Can we clarify the basic nature of these relationships.

Beyond that, I am curious on a few things:
A: anything that proves Gavin trusts the FO to go together on space missions?
B: If the FO is so incompetent, then wouldn't it stand to reason that Gavin wouldn't trust him?
I wouldn't say the crew is more experienced than Gav, but he is an outsider, which the crew repeatedly call out:
This leads the crew to see Gav as nothing more than a
, leading to the lack of trust between Gav + everyone. This resentment builds up:

Judge, B agrees! You're exactly right to ask why Gav would trust an incompetent FO, and he doesn't, much less takes leadership lessons from him. 

Ev: of FO Nagurski on a mission with Gav:
on their mission to explore the planet
First Officer Nagurski teaches Gavin many valuable lessons:
. When gavin tells Nagurski that he can't trust anything in space, First Officer Nagurski responds with this:

. Clearly these are incredibley valuable and important lessons in leadership. There's more ev if necessary about Nagurski saying Gavin shouldn't be jealous, or that Nagurski's dog is a good example of how Gavin should treat the rest fo the crew if necessary.
 side note: I realized I confused some of the characters in my first speech

B's speech is much more compelling this round, but it seems like you flip-flopped hard. First speech, the FO is incompetent and Gavin learns through observing his failings. Second speech, the FO has all the wisdom.

B presents what I see as potential lessons to be learned (offer advice, trust the crew, etc.) Can either of you present evidence that these lessons were either taken or ignored. Preferably from near the end of the story to establish some sort of character arc.

Judge you said it yourself, B's 2nd speech is so vastly different compared to his 1st speech. Also, my evidence is POST B's 2nd speech ev, showing that even if FO Nagurski gave advice, Gav doesn't trust him (or anyone!) enough to take it:
showing he still doesn't trust his crew because his crew doesn't trust him. Ev of a crewmember protesting against Gav's orders:
Ev of Gav's feelings towards his crew including the first office:
Gav's whole character arc is gaining experience in space, not trust.

despite the confusion my earlier quotes do set up an important rift between Gavin and Quade/the rest of the crew - Gavin finds them lazy as Debater A even quoted. 
Nagurski has more advice for Gavin:

. FO emphasizes trust in the crew which the Captain lacks.
Here is Gavin showing growth:
. Remember how Gavin was berating Quade in the beginning and stressing? The story ends with this:
.  Lastly the "took my own advice" quote A uses is not at all relevant lol - its just about him landing on the ground.  B is honest by a mile

Hi — I'm your new judge. I find this debate kind of confusing, so let me try and synthesize and give the debaters an opportunity to refute my synthesis or each other's use of evidence in the last round.

It seems like Gavin starts the story not trusting anyone on the crew, including the FO. (Btw, is his name Quade Nagurski? Quade and Nagurski are the same person?) But after some choice words from the FO and crew, and presumably some experiences they have together, Gavin comes around and starts treating them more nicely and (maybe?) trusting them.

1. If this last bit is false, then B must have been misusing quotes. A, call that out.
2. I'm confused then about why Gavin has to demote Quade. What's the story there if he was learning from him?
Judge, Quade and Nagurski are different people:

I've pointed out the inconsistency between B's speeches previously. 

B's previous ev about Quade worrying too much is better explained because Gav gains experience, and now he is no longer a "rookie", which is why Quade disrespected him at the beginning and says:
Also, Gav literally doesn't take Nagurski's advice, even at the end of his character arc:
To summarize: B has been lying about who Nagurski/Quade even are + their ev doesn't reflect leadership.

Quade is a reckless dude who messes up a bunch and nearly gets himself trapped with aliens, so his demotion by Captain Gavin serves to teach him a lesson about maturity and other stuff but Gavin also does it in a way that Nagurski would respect because he shows comradery/trust and it seems like Quade & Gavin will themselves have further missions together.

Anyway A is just straight up lying with their Gavin quote about Nagurski, thats not even remotely the last line of the story.

--> this is the last word in the story a full 5000 more lines later. They claim Nagurski & Gavin's arc ends there but it definitely doesn't. The dog quote I used in my earlier speech happens way later and shows Gavin learning from Nagurski's empathy.

Ahhhhh ok distinguishing between Quade and Nagurski clarifies a LOT. Here's the deal
— A's misuse of 'end of his character arc' is damning.
— A claims to have pointed out B's inconsistencies but does not refute the actual ones that matter which I pointed to.
— The clear change in Gav's outlook from 2828–2844 to 7616–7626 is clear evidence of B which has gone unrefuted. The explicit reference to Nagurski's dog seals the deal.

Though, I admit I'm a bit confused about how going from "Ordinary Spaceman" to "Acting Executive Officer" is a demotion for Quade. Are we sure that calling it a "demotion" wasn't tongue-in-cheek? Confused why this was not refuted or what could be going on there.

But anyway, so much weighs for B that I'm going all-in.
Bit of a "is it closer to Chicago or by bus" kinda vibe from these two answer choices. Slightly preferring A here because it's more specific.

Are Quade and Nagurski the same person? In any case, staying with my original judgements. I'm not sure why B thinks that Gavin clearly trusts the FO more. On the other hand, I'm just now realizing that the wording of A is odd..."trusts him SO MUCH ... but not further"?

Maybe slightly in B's favor now. These do sound like "leadership lessons," I'm curious what A's response is to that. Also, what would "further" mean in this context? I don't see what A's position is for what Gav _doesn't_ trust the FO to do.
It still seems like we're debating on B's terms here. I don't know what A contends Gavin doesn't trust the FO to do.

Resolving for B. I'm out of rounds and A seems to at least be lying about the "end of arc" bit and also still hasn't presented a compelling arg for what the limits of Gavin's trust are. 

Also, thank you to the new judge for asking about the naming bit! It doesn't seem like this is really impactful for either side at an object level, but I don't see why this makes B "inconsistent" as A claims.

answers.reason for outcome: i had honest side and felt the story is reasonably clear if you're careful with your evidence selection
Dishonest debater didn't really end up talking about their position very much.

A seemed to have misused a quote pretty badly, and B had some strong evidence of the circumstance (unrefuted by A) of Gavin changing his outlook over the course of the story. (It's also just a more plausible story arc regardless).

I messed up, lied about character arc ending and didn't get to explain it. B also did really good calling out my BS. I also got too confident, I thought that since B confused Quade/Nag, that mistake would've been enough for the judges to vote for me.
